title: Memoirs of his own life: by Tate Wilkinson, ... In four volumes. ... [pt.3]
author: Wilkinson, Tate
snippet: I was really in a puzzling situation, being actually engaged with company at four o'clock at the worthy Corne us Kelly's in Capel-street, who was then beloved and known by every body, and I believe is yet living, and must be a surprising age.

title: Early Travellers in Scotland. Edited by P. Hume Brown. [With maps.]
author: Brown, Peter Hume.
snippet: The Gentlemen reckon theirrevenewes, not by rents of monie, but by chauldrons ofvictuals, and keepe many people in their Families, yet livingmost on Corne and Rootes, not spending any great quantityon flesh.

title: Early Travellers in Scotland. Edited by P. Hume Brown. [With maps.]
author: Brown, Peter Hume.
snippet: Withoutinclosures, fruitfull in Corne (as bee all the parses neareBarwick, save that they yeeld little wheate, and much Barleyand Oates), and all a plaine Country, but it had no Woodesat all, onely the Gentleniens dwellings were shaddowed withsome little Groves, pleasant to the view.

title: Early Travellers in Scotland. Edited by P. Hume Brown. [With maps.]
author: Brown, Peter Hume.
snippet: Camden saith thisCastle was of old called by the Britaines, Castle meyned agned,by the Scots ; the Castle of the Maids or Virgines (of certaineVirgines kept there for the Kings of the Picts), and byPtolemy the winged Castle.3 And from this Castle towardsthe West, is a most steepe Rocke pointed on the highesttop, out of which this Castle is cut: But on the North andSouth sides without the wals, lie plaine and fruitfull fieldsof Corne.
